Supreme Court ruled a search of a police pager was reasonable (work-related purpose). Rejected 'least intrusive means' test for workplace searches.
Employees using personal devices have a **higher expectation of privacy** than on company-owned equipment.
Employers can monitor calls/emails if there is a legitimate business reason, but must stop if content is personal.

Federal: One-party consent.
Some states: All-party consent.
Requires both **prior written notice** AND **daily electronic notice** (e.g., login banner).
Requires **prior written notice** of monitoring types.
Business can generally open ALL mail delivered to office, even if marked 'Private'.
Must be evenhanded. Employers liable if investigator fails to conduct an effective investigation (EEOC 'Reasonable Care').
NOT consumer reports if: 1. Related to misconduct/compliance. 2. No credit info. 3. Limited sharing (implied no prior consent needed).
DOL requires FMLA health info be kept in a **separate file** from the general personnel file.
Insurers/Agencies not HIPAA entities, but HIPAA allows providers to disclose PHI to them w/o authorization to comply with laws.

1. Revoke access.
2. Request data deletion from personal devices.
3. Remind of confidentiality obligations.
Must take 'reasonable measures' to destroy background checks/credit reports in former employee files.
Must provide letter stating length of employment, job classification, and pay rate upon request.
Liability for false/damaging statements. Many employers use a **'Neutral Reference' Policy** (dates/title only).
